caption: Table 1: A comparison of different temperature values
description: This table presents the average scores obtained for different temperature values during the grid search for partial tuning. The temperature parameter is inversely proportional to the temperature used for calculating the contrastive loss, which directly impacts the quality of the embeddings produced.  The results indicate that a temperature inverse of 40 yields the best performance, suggesting an optimal balance between the positive and negative pairs during the contrastive learning process.
section: E.2 Temperature and weight decay for partial tuning

caption: Table 2: Mean pooling works better than last pooling.
description: This table presents a comparison of the average scores obtained using two different pooling methods: mean pooling and last pooling. The results show that mean pooling achieves a higher average score (0.47) compared to last pooling (0.36), indicating that mean pooling is a more effective method for this task.

caption: Table 3: Learning rate for LoRA.
description: This table presents the results of a hyperparameter search for the learning rate used in LoRA fine-tuning.  Three different LoRA ranks (8, 16, and 32) were tested, each with three different learning rates (1e2, 1e3, and 1e4). The loss achieved for each combination of LoRA rank and learning rate is shown.  The table helps in determining the optimal learning rate for different LoRA ranks.

caption: Table 1: A comparison of different temperature values
description: This table shows the average score achieved on a subset of MTEB benchmark for different temperature values used during the training of embedding models with partial tuning. The best score is 0.51, achieved with temperature = 40.
section: E.2 Temperature and weight decay for partial tuning
